column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.RoleAnnotation|roles
#Text=Mr.
#Text=Selim (Egypt) (spoke in Arabic): I would like\r
#Text=to thank the Kingdom of Spain and the President of the\r
#Text=Government of Spain for taking the initiative to convene\r
#Text=today's meeting on women and peace and security on\r
#Text=the fifteenth anniversary of the adoption of resolution\r
#Text=1325 (2000), and for inviting us to participate.
#Text=I would also like to thank the Secretary-General for\r
#Text=his efforts to highlight this important issue, including in\r
#Text=his most recent report on the resolution's implementation\r
#Text=(S/2015/7l6), which particularly emphasizes the\r
#Text=problem of resolving the crises facing us of the lack\r
#Text=of financing and inequitable selectivity in allocating\r
#Text=financial resources, as well as the direct links that the\r
#Text=report highlights among development issues, including\r
#Text=the importance of supporting countries' efforts to help\r
#Text=their peoples achieve their aspirations and of protecting\r
#Text=women in armed conflict and post-conflict situations.
#Text=Egypt supports the Secretary-General's call to promote\r
#Text=the role of women in its peacekeeping operations and its\r
#Text=mediation and conflict-resolution efforts.
#Text=Our discussion of the issues related to resolution\r
#Text=1325 (2000) has touched on the lack of adequate\r
#Text=attention to some of the chief problems it is aimed at,\r
#Text=in particular the degree to which women suffer under\r
#Text=foreign occupation, as well as the effects that can result\r
#Text=from an overemphasis on the connection between\r
#Text=international human rights law and international\r
#Text=humanitarian law, which can weaken the systems\r
#Text=available for providing protection in both peace and\r
#Text=war through the politicization of positions on the\r
#Text=various issues linked to the two types of law.
#Text=Another\r
#Text=is insufficient attention to the priorities of national\r
#Text=sovereignty and respect for national legislation, along\r
#Text=with a reliance on unofficial studies that may not be as\r
#Text=precise in evaluating the progress made in achieving\r
#Text=goals for women and peace and security.
#Text=Terrorism is a threat to peace and security, along\r
#Text=with the armed conflicts that afflict many States and\r
#Text=regions around the world.
#Text=In most cases, in fact, it forms\r
#Text=an integral part of every conflict.
#Text=That is a threat our\r
#Text=communities face, and the threat level has increased of\r
#Text=late.
#Text=It has affected States' abilities to carry out their\r
#Text=aspirations in terms of development and prosperity.
#Text=Although terrorism threatens the whole of society,\r
#Text=women are the most vulnerable.
#Text=That is a cause to\r
#Text=which we will accord great interest as a non-permanent\r
#Text=member of the Security Council.
#Text=Egypt accords great interest to issues of women\r
#Text=and their role as a pivotal element in building and\r
#Text=maintaining peace.
#Text=That interest is based on Egypt's\r
#Text=efforts in promoting the position of women in different\r
#Text=areas.
#Text=It goes hand in hand with Egypt's broader vision\r
#Text=of the empowerment of women at all levels.
#Text=Egypt has\r
#Text=supported the goals and rationale of resolution 1325\r
#Text=(2000) since its adoption, back in 2000, given the\r
#Text=importance of this and subsequent resolutions with\r
#Text=respect to the cause of women in conflict and post-\r
#Text=conflict situations.
#Text=In that regard, Egypt's support has\r
#Text=taken many forms at both the regional and international\r
#Text=levels.
#Text=The National Council for Women of Egypt\r
#Text=has worked out a national plan for follow-up and\r
#Text=implementation of resolution 1325 (2000) in the\r
#Text=framework of the active role played by women in the\r
#Text=area of international conflict resolution.
#Text=Egypt has\r
#Text=become one of 17 African States to develop that kind of\r
#Text=national plan.
#Text=Over the last 15 years, since the adoption\r
#Text=of the resolution, Egypt has held a number of activities\r
#Text=on that issue.
#Text=Two regional workshops were organized,\r
#Text=jointly with the United Nations and the League of Arab\r
#Text=States.
#Text=Egypt has accorded special attention to issues\r
#Text=of training and capacity-building.
#Text=From 2013 to 2015,\r
#Text=the Cairo Regional Centre for Training on Conflict-\r
#Text=Resolution and Peacekeeping in Africa has held seven\r
#Text=training courses, two courses for the training of trainers\r
#Text=and a workshop, all dedicated to habilitating staff and\r
#Text=to exchanging expertise on the implementation of\r
#Text=resolution 1325 (2000), under the theme "Inclusion\r
#Text=of gender in peacekeeping and peace building", to\r
#Text=be complemented by the holding of five additional\r
#Text=training courses in the same vein up to June 2016.
#Text=In conclusion, I would like to reiterate my\r
#Text=appreciation for the call to convene this important\r
#Text=meeting, in which we have been eager to participate in\r
#Text=the framework of Egypt's support for the efforts of the\r
#Text=United Nations, and the Security Council in particular,\r
#Text=to promote the role and status of women.
#Text=Egypt will\r
#Text=also be sure to follow up on these issues regionally and\r
#Text=internationally in the context of its efforts to achieve\r
#Text=peace and security.
